content.user_title: Create isolated git worktrees for parallel development
content.value_statement: Managing multiple git branches can clutter your main working directory and make context switching difficult. This skill provides a structured approach to creating isolated git worktrees that let you work on multiple features simultaneously without interference.
actual_capabilities: Create isolated git worktrees with smart directory naming
Verify worktree safety before and after creation
Follow consistent naming conventions for worktrees
limitations: Does not execute git commands automatically
Requires git version 2.5 or higher for worktree support
Does not handle merge conflicts in worktrees
Does not create or modify remote branches

use_cases.title: Isolate feature development
use_cases.description: Create separate worktrees for different features to maintain clean context and avoid polluting your main working directory.

use_cases.title: Review pull requests
use_cases.description: Check out PR branches in isolated worktrees without disrupting your current development work.

use_cases.title: Handle urgent hotfixes
use_cases.description: Create temporary worktrees for critical fixes while preserving your active development environment.

prompt_templates.title: Create a worktree
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a new git worktree for a feature called [feature-name] based on the main branch. Follow the worktree naming conventions and verify the environment is safe before creating it.

prompt_templates.title: Set up parallel worktrees
prompt_templates.prompt: List all existing worktrees and then create a new worktree for [feature-name] and another for [another-feature] in parallel.

prompt_templates.title: Review in isolation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an isolated worktree for reviewing PR #123. Verify the worktree was created correctly and list all current worktrees.

prompt_templates.title: Clean up worktrees
prompt_templates.prompt: List all worktrees, remove the ones named [feature-old] and [feature-experiment], then prune any orphaned references.

output_examples.input: Create a worktree for a new authentication feature
output: New branch feature/authentication created from main
Verification: git worktree list shows the new worktree

best_practices: Keep all worktrees in a consistent location like ../worktrees/
Use clear naming conventions that indicate the worktree purpose
Remove worktrees promptly after completing work to avoid clutter
anti_patterns: Creating worktrees directly in the project root
Using generic names like 'test' or 'temp' for worktrees
Leaving unused worktrees that accumulate over time

faq.question: Which git versions support worktrees?
faq.answer: Git worktrees require git version 2.5 or higher. Most modern git installations include this feature.

faq.question: Can I have unlimited worktrees?
faq.answer: The number of worktrees is limited only by system resources. Each worktree is a full checkout of the repository.

faq.question: How do worktrees integrate with Claude Code?
faq.answer: This skill works with Read, Glob, Grep, and Bash tools to help you create and manage worktrees through natural language.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using worktrees?
faq.answer: Yes. Worktrees are isolated copies. Changes in one worktree do not affect others until you merge or push.

faq.question: Why do I get 'already checked out' errors?
faq.answer: This error means another worktree is already using the same directory. Use a different branch name or directory.

faq.question: How is this different from cloning the repository?
faq.answer: Worktrees share the .git folder with the main repository, making them more space-efficient and easier to synchronize.
